Ansh Chandnani

Offensive Cyber Security, Swimming, Public Speaking.

Throughout the years of my life I have gained a vast perspectives, skills, and practices. From primary schooling in Dubai to completing the last 6 years of high school in Kolkata, India and working diligently to pursue Cybersecurity in the USA. In addition to my Programming, Communication, and Security skills; I recognise myself as a disciplined and hardworking individual.

By means of this blog I intend to address intriguing socio-technical issues affecting various age groups in this Infomation age. Everything from collosal space arks to the tiniest of tardigrades, surveillance capitalism, and everything in between. This is the one stop forum for any thing that itchs your metaphorical beard.

item.title: The Limits of Our Technology
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
'What begins must have an end. But where there is an end; there is also a new beginning.'
The world saw immense progress in the technological era, if you will, that began in the late 70s. Transistors, Logic Gates, Processors allowed the human race to customize, perpetuate, discover, invent; for the good and the not so good. Throughout the period of 36 years till date we have seen machinery in general become more compact, more intelligent, adaptive and efficient. A single transistor can be as tiny as 14 nm in width; to scale that is eight times smaller than the HIV virus and about 500 times smaller than a red blood cell!  Controversially the smaller a part gets the more does quantum physics play it's part. In a nutshell quantum physics allows a substance to exist in various states of possibilities at the same time, until observed. Electricity flowing as electrons could possibly overcome a switch (in this case a transistors) through a process called quantum tunneling, thus rendering the entire mechanism of computing futile. However, pay heed to the second part of the quote at the top. Quantum physics allows something called quantum entanglement, generally speaking the state of one substance affects the state of the other no matter how far apart they might be. It is based on this mechanism that a Quantum Computer works, speeding calculations. Quantum computers perform functions at the square root of time that a regular computer would take. Plus why not simulate the realm of the Quantum world with a quantum computer itself? The crux is to evaluate not how far we have progressed but how much more we can. To widen our perspective. To discover the colossal and the infinitesimal. Check this link for more information:  Kurzgesagt-Quantum Computers

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great ! Had never heard of it! Keep it up.

item.title: Conquering Stars
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
There was a significant amount of commotion when renowned theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking announced that humans had only 1000 years till a mass extinction would wipe out all complex life forms on Earth. In reality this has happened 5 times in the 4.6 billion years of our planet's life; the most known and recent one being that of the Dinosaurs. At this stage we have two choices:
  1.  Accept defeat and live till we can
  2. Colonize other habitable planets to continue the human race
Now if you think about it the second option is worth a try, and even if we fail we technically have nothing to lose. Colonizing other worlds isn't really just a science fiction thing. A scale called the Kardashev scale denotes how technologically advanced a civilization is it is divided into 3 types: TYPE 1: The civilization that is capable of utilizing all available resources on it's host planet. TYPE 2: The civilization that has harnessed the energy and resources throughout it's star system. This is feasible in the form of a Dyson Sphere/Storm. A Dyson Sphere is a structure that is capable of harnessing all the energy from a star; a Dyson Storm is a group of smart robots capable of replicating themselves for the purpose of exploration and colonization. TYPE 3: The civilization that rules an entire galaxy. If you're wondering humans currently stand at 0.73. But do not lose hope! If we did find Earth 2 out there we could still take humans on a large scale with existing technology. Information regarding that would bore you if I wrote it down so check this link:PBS Space Time- Interstellar Travel. Whether we do rule the galaxy or not is a question to be answered by the generations to come; what we should do individually is take care of the resources that are in our hands first; Mother Earth.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: So true. Future can be left for generations to come. But we have to learn to take care of mother earth in the real actions.

item.title: The 6th Mass Extinction?
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
Our planet has this intriguing mechanism that never lets a species exist indefinitely. Every once in a while, geologically speaking, the most dominant species on Earth either gets wiped out significantly or shrinks to a size that is negligible when compared to its dominant form. A lesser known fact among the common public is that Planet Earth has already unleashed her fury to cause 5 Mass Extinctions or Biotic Crisis's.  The one that occurs to us at this point is the most recent, the Dinosaur Extinction. The much deliberated topic upon which the most widely accepted theory is the one where a huge meteorite lay waste to most life. However, it is crucial to understand the fact that there was no time at which an entire species was wiped out completely; as I said most of the organisms of the dominant species are wiped out. A question that may arise to one's mind: Can we predict the next Mass Extinction? Answer: Yes, we can and we already have. Humans have been the dominant species on this planet for roughly 200,000 years. As Stephen Hawking predicted recently the human race has less than a thousand years left on this planet. Of course this lead to widespread turmoil in the scientific community. The sad truth between these lines is we have actually catalyzed our end voluntarily! I'll save the word count by not quoting environmental degradation, global warming, etc. 'cause you get the point. Statistics reveal that when a species gets comfortable in a habitat, its future generations tend to show a gradual decline in height.
The most reasonable explanation to this phenomenon is that the body of the organism, having no longer the necessity to fight for it's survival expends less energy on physical and muscular growth and inclines towards intellectual development. Take a look at the sharp decline on the graph in the middle of the Iron Age, probably the most comfortable period in pre-modern human history. That's the reason we built the computer after the world wars and significantly after the cave man age. According to all mythologies around the world, specifically Indian mythology, Humans were about 10 feet tall on an average. This is proved by the large doorways and ancient structures that survive till date. There is also a colossal footprint, said to be of the Indian mythological figure Ghatotkach, preserved till date; along with skeletons larger than we have ever seen. To come to think about it, tiny Lizards are descendants of the sky-scraping Dinosaurs, right?
This change is minutely visible in day to day life too, you are generally taller than someone who is 2-3 years younger than you. This subject is one of my fields of research; among the others you will hopefully read about in later posts. Okay, so... Is it the end of the line for us? Nope. Not until we give up. We've all heard about genetic engineering, and DNA changing; something like getting modified abilities, rather engineering them in a lab and then putting in in ourselves(sounds like an X-Men movie doesn't it?). Nature always has a solution. Meet the Tardigrade. 5 time apocalypse champion.
Source: BBC , Google Images
Tardigrades are semi-microscopic organisms that can survive in the most inhospitable conditions of even space! A few laboratory tardigrades were sent up to the ISS and thrown into space for 10 days. Collect them, come back to Earth and guess what? They were healthy as ever. A team of researchers at University of North Carolina actually detected upto 18% of forgein DNA in them; theories suggest that when exposed to inhospitable environments these creatures can alter their DNA. Think of the possibilities that are now open. What if we finally have the answer of breaking the Human Genetic Code? What if we can alter our DNA? Could we go to space without having to wear spacesuits? Take is as food for thought.
item.excerpt:encoded: Our planet has this intriguing mechanism that never lets a species exist indefinitely. Every once in a while, geologically speaking, the most dominant species on Earth either gets wiped out significantly or shrinks to a size that is negligible when compared to its dominant form. Is it our turn now?

item.title: Water bear, SEM
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.excerpt:encoded: Water bear. Coloured scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of a water bear (Paramacrobiotus craterlaki) in moss. Water bears (or tardigrades) are tiny invertebrates that live in aquatic and semi-aquatic habitats such as lichen and damp moss. Paramacrobiotus craterlaki is a carnivorous species that feeds on nematodes and rotifers. Water bears are found throughout the world, including regions of extreme temperature, such as hot springs, and extreme pressure, such as deep underwater. They can also survive the high levels of radiation and vacuum of space. Magnification: x330 when printed at 10 centimetres wide.

item.title: The Mythology of Science
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
Controversies exist practically everywhere; ranging from logical paradoxes like the Fermi Paradox and capabilities of Artificial Intelligence, and sarcastically legendary ones like flat earth theory. However probably the most intriguing of them all happens to be the deliberation on Mythology vs. Science. The two facets have been deliberated upon since the dawn of curiosity and thirst for reason; giving rise to atheism and sometimes resulting in clashes that are not always peaceful. Today let us look at the two paradigms and try to unite them as one. Interested? We've seen till date the isolation of the two sets, today I wish to create a Venn Diagram (if you will) and outline the areas of intersection and how one may have given birth to the other. Religion was the root of Mythology, it outlined different stories of origin of the Universe and Earth. Every religion has it's own mythology: Greek, Aztec, Jewish, Hindu, Nordic, etc.  What's keen to note is there are some events in every mythology that are common not only to other religions and beliefs but also to certain scientific theories. Taking one for example, the Great Flood in Abraham-origin reference is explained as:
  1. A flood to exterminate Cyclops and Hundred Handed ones in Greek Mythology.
  2. An attempt to unwind life and begin from the start in Hindu and Sumerian Mythologies.
  3. Now the interesting part is that it is scientifically determined that the second ice age had an abrupt end. There was an apparent flood that increased sea levels globally.
The burden of proof I'm getting to is simple: Mythology & Science are the same things viewed from different frames of references. Mythology, spiritualism and religion have focused on the effects of natural occurrences while science tends to identify the root cause behind every phenomenon. The similarity? Both arise from the human nature of curiosity. Allow me to illustrate with a simple theory I conceived. Teleportation. General Quantum Mechanics states that any entity has a dual nature - particle and wave. If an entity in motion is kept in a container its wavelength signifies the maximum probability of position. Although it's maximum probability lies within the container; a narrow probability lingers of the entity 'tunneling' its way and appearing outside the container.
[caption id="attachment_241" align="alignnone" width="1366"] Quantum Tunneling[/caption] source : www.youtube.com/pbsspacetime
Now, the act of meditation as outlined by all religions is a method to calm the mind. Psychologically speaking when you focus your mind you are calming all the organs, cells in your body; you try and take all your cerebral capacity and will to focus it on one particular goal or activity. For macro-scopic objects the particle nature dominates the wave function therefore we perceive them holding a fixed position rather than a range of possibilities. Furthermore, any observable movement will allow the particle nature to become prominent i.e.  we visualize that part of the wave function which signifies highest probability of position. The hypothesis I'm coming to is what if through meditation ancient humans were capable of utilizing their cerebral capacity to the extent where they calm each atom down to a state where they exist momentarily as a wave-function and reinstate particle motion when they want to be "normal." This mechanism allows at least a faint explanation to authentic ancient texts. One may now ask, have we actually taken a progressive step backwards regarding development? The answer is: No. Agreeable by changing frames of references we might have not been able to understand flying chariots or rainbow bridges to the heavens. But we have made significant steps forward. And accept the fact that each change requires us to start from square one. But we can accelerate the process by taking into account our past and present to move towards a better future (hopefully with hover boards). ;)

item.title: Artificial Intelligence
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
Imagine being the one to create a race of intelligent, self-sustaining, curious, emotional beings; did God ever anticipate atheism the way we anticipate the dominance of Artificial Intelligence? Today we face what can be said to be a "moral crisis." There is a time when an inventor outdoes himself, creates an entity that may lead to revolutionizing the world but be the cause of his/her demise.  Artificial Intelligence entails the programming of an intangible working responsive 'program' that behaves intuitively. The conventional form of computing allowed work to be done provided each step had a command or algorithm associated with it. However, artificial intelligence as the name suggests is when a machine can learn like a human brain when circuitry can adapt like our neurons. Learn like a child. In both cases the advantage remains the same, machines are immune to fatigue and circuit relays operate at speeds close to the speed of light. The human thought process, on the other hand, is seemingly restrictive, we have a fixed number of neurons. And a limited amount of tasks that our brain can perform. Let's say our brain is the preset, unalterable Mac Book whereas a configured artificial intelligence is an assembled computer with whatever capabilities you want it to have (to a certain extent, limitless; ironic isn't it?). Artificial Intelligence has potentials unimagined as of the present times, what we've tapped is probably less than 1% of it's potential. To sum up: Google's DeepMind AI taught itself how to walk! Facebook's AI created its own language! Amazon's Alexa is already capable as a full virtual home assistant (yay, Iron Man? Not yet). Before we jump any further, it is crucial to note that AI works on 7 key ideas/motives:
  1. Stimulating higher functions of the human brain.
  2. Programming a computer to use general language.
  3. Arranging hypothetical (virtual) neurons in a manner enabling it to form 'concepts.'
  4. A way to determine and measure problem complexity.
  5. Self Improvement.
  6. Abstraction defined as the ability to deal with ideas instead of events or objects.
  7. Randomness and Creativity.
Artificial Intelligence essentially attempts to become (not mimic) like a human brain, probably better. It's a consciousness without the limits of a 'body' or a physical container. Sounds limitless right? We humans cannot transfer our consciousness from body to body but any artificial intelligence, even ones that exist today, can simply 'upload' themselves on another platform. It is an abstract thought process that can take up any form, anybody, any manifestation. A consciousness that can be used in explorers for space expeditions, for marine robots to discover the depths of the marina trench; the most impressive part? AI can choose its modifications, it's own workable tangible parts. Undoubtedly AI is one of humanity's greatest creations. And as expected, is there a catch? showman's voice "Well of course!!" Many notable personalities, such as Stephen Hawking & Elon Musk, are afraid of the exponential uncontrolled rise of AI; because out of the million possible outcomes: one is the idea that AI will one day succeed its creators and pose as a threat to our very existence. This moment was first anticipated by John Von Neumann when he coined it as 'The Singularity'. In the 2012 Singularity Summit numerous dates of The Singularity have anticipated whose median value came up to the year 2040 A.D. This poses a large number of questions:
  1.  Is it reasonable to abandon AI research and development?
  2. Is AI indeed a liability than an asset?
  3. What are the long-term implications to the development of AI?
  4. If AI is our creation why are we afraid of controlling it?
  5. Can we ever control AI to its full extent?
It isn't just us, but everyone in the research facilities pondering upon these questions. It is these questions, whose answers may guide the course of humanity's near future. Just a bit of food for thought: If we need AI, but its development should be under limitations, what are some of the measures we must take to enable our control over our creations?
item.excerpt:encoded: Imagine being the one to create a race of intelligent, self-sustaining, curious, emotional beings; did God ever anticipate atheism the way we anticipate dominance of Artificial Intelligence?

item.title: The Viability of Cyber Deterrence
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
A common methodology exploited by the human race was to "deter" a threat before it even occurred. Initially, the concept revolved around deterrence by denial: which basically prevents an attack by making it expensive or not profitable for the attacker. with the advent of Nuclear weapons and warfare, the idea of deterrence changed; it was now deterrence by punishment. Countries developed nuclear arsenal not to use it on other nations during warfare, but to dissuade opponents and enemies from ever engaging in one in the first place. We legit had an entire proxy war based on this strategy and the plot for Captain America: The Winter Soldier. Jokes aside, with the evolvement of cyberspace, it is virtually impossible to know who's conducting an attack in the first place. Why do we need deterrence? Deterrence has so far proven to be one of the most effective concepts in preventing an attack. Just by building up a strong defense an attacker is dissuaded from conducting harm against you. The predominant approach to theorizing about deterrence has entailed the use of rational choice and game-theoretic models of decision making (see game theory). Deterrence theorists have consistently argued that deterrence success is more likely if a defending state's deterrent threat is credible to an attacking state. At this juncture, it is crucial to understand that while the conventional theory of deterrence relies on certain factors such as attribution and motive, the very existence of cyberspace makes it extremely difficult (if not guarantees) to take these factors into consideration. Essentially you are asking a defense agency to deter an attack against an unknown threat with an unknown motive. Tough? That'll be an understatement. Challenges to Deterrence and Dissuasion in Cyberspace: 
  1. Attribution: the virtual world is like a Minecraft simulation where the world literally has no end. Here exploiters don't hide in corners (there aren't any in the first place). The development of Cyber Space negates the possibility of pinpointing accurately the source or identity behind the attack, anonymity is very much a possibility in the Cyber realm and is continuously being exploited. You cannot deter by punishment because you essentially don't even know who to punish.
  2. Motive & Drive: deterrence policies are largely shaped based on the identity of the attacker. The identity of a potential hacker leads defense agencies and strategists to tailor their policies according to a calculated motive of the attacker. Sure, it would be better to secure all fronts of a system or network but frankly, that's too much work and leaves no room for specialized protection of certain assets. This implies that without a specific idea of the attackers' motive only a generalistic security measure can be sanctioned.
  3. Dynamics: The virtual world changes every second. The sheer dynamic nature of cyberspace makes it impossible for security analysts to come up with a definitive strategy of protection. Any existing strategy and program too would have to be subject to constant updates and checks to prove to be even slightly useful. Windows Defender, take a hint, please.
Which brings us the million dollar question: is deterrence and dissuasion as a concept still applicable in cyberspace? Understanding that this article may have now dissuaded you from hoping for a possibility to apply this amazing concept to everyone's favorite addiction- hope remains. Keeping in mind the fundamentals of this concept, there is a third lesser known form of deterrence: deterrence by entanglement. If an attack conducted by a party harms itself to a certain extent it wouldn't be conducted. If today China were to hack into the US domain of the World Wide Web it would ultimately be detrimental to China as most of the revenue of Chinese products come from e-commerce sites and online economic opportunities. With the world being increasingly interdependent it may be beneficial to security analysts to consider the above scenario. Moreover, instead of focussing so much on tracking and punishing hackers it may be wiser to just stick with the rudimentary concept of deterrence by denial. Building a system that secures itself as it progresses. It is here that the concept of Artificial Intelligence comes into play. Primarily the most fascinating characteristic of AI is the idea of an adaptable system, which can not only read from commands but also learn as it is being operated on to generate the most fruitful result. Imagine a system that continuously upgrades itself and learns about how hackers and exploiters are developing- triggering itself to employ a new strategy.
item.excerpt:encoded: How do security analysts come up with a definitive strategy to prevent hacking? What prevents exploiters from breaking into systems? Is the most effective concept of defense failing against the expanses of CyberSpace?

item.title: Sentience
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded: Ever pondered on the question of your existence? Ever asked yourself: Who am I? The fine line that separates living organisms from our advanced technology is the concept of Sentience-being self-aware. Philosophers first defined sentience in the 18th Century as the capacity to feel, perceive, or experience subjectively. It is, therefore, the active consciousness a biotic creature possesses that distinguishes it from an abiotic entity. As technology progresses, machines are essentially being "taught" how to act intuitively, a characteristic that was only associated with humans for a long period of time. However, with the advent of machine learning and neural networks, the line between conscious and unconscious seems blurred. Whether this development is a boon or a bane, is a debate for another time. As of today there exist several skepticisms regarding the development of Artificial Intelligence. It becomes crucial to note that almost all (if not all) of these assumptions and fears stem from the belief that Artificial Intelligence would someday become conscious about their existence and therefore pose a threat to humanity (anyone here remembers Ultron?). I understand that this may raise more questions than I intended to address, but bear with me for a bit. Understand that sentience and consciousness as a concept are still vague to a certain extent. Invoking abstract concepts such as emotions into a machine may still be a thing of the distant future for us. Let us consider for the sake of argument that one-day technology does evolve and become self-aware or sentient. What does this imply for the human race, or for that matter all conventional lifeforms on this planet? Take into consideration that machines were invented in order to aid us in tasks that would ordinarily be very difficult or impossible to do with our bare hands. Granting the capabilities of actions which cannot be done by the human race along with the concept of sentience hints towards a new race which will possibly be more advanced than our own. At a recent event by Google, the CEO, Sundar Pichai, demonstrated how Google Duplex AI makes a call to a salon to make an appointment. The AI seamlessly made the call, reserved a time slot and even stuttered like a normal human would. The human recieving the call had no clue that she was talking to an AI. This is essentially the Turing Test. A Turing Test ,basically, is used to determine whether or not an AI or a machine is distinguishable from a human; Google AI has successfully passed this test. Humans have an inherent bias within them. When we create artificially intelligent beings they too possess the same bias. Therefore we are essentially on the road to create beings that are physically more capable than us but mentally and psychologically extremely similar. It is based on these assumptions and hypotheses that a lot of influencers in the world of technology believe that the unrestricted development of Artificial Intelligence would ultimately be harmful to us. This idea of technology someday becoming smarter than the human race is known as the technological singularity. Side note: there are a lot of Ted Talks on this that are pretty cool. Keeping these reservations aside, the full potential of AI can only be understood once we engage in the field to a considerable extent. Fearing futuristic technology isn't a safeguard against its development. If we were to protect ourselves against such a situation, it seems better to understand the field completely.
item.excerpt:encoded: Ever pondered on the question of your existence? Ever asked yourself: Who am I? The fine line that separates living organisms from our advanced technology is the concept of Sentience-being self-aware.

item.title: Hacking Toasters
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
The era of semiconductors. Our day to day lives have become so deeply interwoven with technology; it is hard to imagine an instant where smart technology isn't involved. Wake up, read your messages, check your Instagram, tell Siri to play some music, make some coffee, use the toaster to get that perfect golden brown tint. Now, don't get me wrong, I'm not against these activities (I do them too). However, it strikes me, at certain times, as to how dependent we have become on technology to get through our day. The human race has spent millenniums changing the environment around us to suit our needs and wants. Ever since the dawn of civilization we've strived to influence our environment to increase our comfort levels. Gone are the days where we worried about survival or predators, we worry about college admissions and Wall Street now. It is through this progression that today we have microchips and an interface in almost every appliance now. Television sets can now do so much more than just broadcast a show, our phones are becoming handheld computers, and some refrigerators can control washing machines and vice versa. If your toaster doesn't have an interface yet, just wait, chances are its already in development. The underlying point being- as every bit of technology around us becomes 'smarter' for the purpose of efficiency it poses a threat to us (not going to talk about a robot uprising) in the sense that everything with a decent processor and microchip or integrated circuit can be hacked. Sure security protocols are in place and a lot of people are working on securing devices, understand that a lot of this attention goes to mobile devices and laptops when a similar amount of damage could be inflicted by hacking a television. How this may go about is related to the way our devices tend to interconnect these days. Your phone may be completely up to date on its security protocols but if your television is hacked which may be connected to your phone... With the advent of the Internet of Things such tasks are relatively easy.
Consumers should understand the crucial role they play in cybersecurity, especially in regard to IoT devices, which have become increasingly accessible and vulnerable to hacking incidents. -Forbes
This necessitates an effort to secure all 'smart devices' with similar, if not same, vigor as our phones and laptops. Having highlighted the importance of cybersecurity, it is crucial to think of ways to combat this situation. Let's face it, smart devices really make our lives comfortable but we can't afford to let personal data get away. Cybersecurity and ideas related to cyberspace are becoming crucial as technology develops. The idea is to live in a world where the logistics are already taken care of, an environment so friendly to provide us with immense comfort. It becomes essential to secure all devices. But, the next time your toaster doesn't give that golden brown please don't blame it on hackers trying to give you a bad day. ;) Read more?

The underlying point being- as every bit of technology around us becomes 'smarter' for the purpose of efficiency it poses a threat to us.

item.title: Egoistic Altruism
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded: What does it take to be better off in this world? Is there a full proof way to acquire gains and profit? For most of human history resources and the economy have been a zero-sum game. For a person to be better off, someone else had to be worse off. If you wanted more food, another region would have to be put in famine. This was the fundamental basis as to why countries invaded each other and why pre-industrial times were characterized by huge economic differences. However, all this changed with the advent of the industrial revolution. Once we figured out a method to manufacture more products and take advantage of more resources, the competition for goods reduced. This wasn't just the case in the agricultural sector but in every sector of the economy. The revolution brought about the advent of sectors of manufacture, transport, and other services. This brought about a change in the construct of our societies. The world went from being a zero-sum game to a positive-sum game. As productivity increased there was a scope of exporting goods after satisfying the needs of the endemic population. Eventually, methods of production and manufacture were improved upon and productivity kept increasing. The change from a world of economic stagnation to one of economic growth was a result of innovation. New ideas, technology, and inventions fueled the development of better ways at production and consumption. Innovation gave us better solutions to existing problems and methods to solve problems we didn't know existed. Innovation is driven by two factors: supply and demand. The more people in the world want something, the more researchers, inventors, and thinkers spend time and resources making ideas into reality. In a positive-sum world, ensuring people are better off can ultimately be advantageous to you. This brings in the concept of egoistic altruism. By individual definition, this seems like an oxymoron. However, as a concept, it may be the next best strategy into the concept of development. Take for example the wish to find a cure for cancer. Currently, the world can invest only so much into research for a cure, but if the number of people investing grew as a result of better lifestyles and more earning potential this particular quest would be further motivated to come up with a cure as a result of the increasing demand. As people become richer and more educated they have an increased potential to go after such demands. Instead of having a few niches of innovation in the world, the world could be a single large network of niches. Contributing ideas, inventions, and theories would eventually facilitate a better lifestyle for everyone on this planet. If every nation in the world had a thriving space program, the demand for colonies in space would be met much sooner. If more people knew and valued medical research, there would be far fewer diseases. No matter how selfish we are or can be people are valuable to us when they contribute to the global forum.
item.excerpt:encoded: What does it take to be better off in this world? Is there a full proof way to acquire gains and profit?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: […] a previous blog post exploring the concept of Egoistic Altruism, it was outlined that humans are more valuable to us alive than dead due to the dynamic of a […]
What an interesting idea....... Does this mean that a person can be selfish but ultimately it will provide for the greater good under certain circumstances?
Exactly. That's the beauty of this concept.

item.title: Integration
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
As much as my nerdy, math-loving self wants, I can't make this blog about calculus. This is supposed to be about the integration of technology, focus Ansh. Focus.
Almost all of us use apps and programs to accomplish simple tasks. Whether it is to book a cab, dine out at a restaurant or even remember when to shower the cat. The inclusion of technology in our lives seems like a gradual process yet about 30 years ago it was negligible. So what changed? And why did we change? Transitions are tedious, time-consuming processes. Not a lot of people wanted to believe the Earth wasn't the center of the universe. Not a lot of people thought the Earth was spherical. Almost all transitions in human history have taken a significant amount of time, resources and guillotined lives. But somehow this one transition, in particular, was seemingly seamless? Hurray, Steve Jobs? No. The nature of the transition from a low technology dependent lifestyle to our current lifestyle was a relatively different transition. Probably unlike any other, we've seen. A common feature of social or political change is the temporary unrest it causes. However, it is crucial to note that the integration of technology, although a change, created no such disequilibrium. This is primarily due to the fundamental nature of technology. Technology from the very beginning was driven by the goal to impact every single life in a positive way. A mass consumption amenity that is versatile enough to be advantageous to everyone who uses it, be it rich, poor, intelligent, or mediocre. The advent of appliances like the computer or the mobile phone provided a level increase in comfort. The demand for such appliances was present much before their creation. Which brings me to the crux of this article, integration of technology. It is somewhat juvenile to try to come to a concrete notion of whether this integration is good or bad. Understand that "good" and "bad" are subjective terms. The extensive use of technology has both beneficial and detrimental effects. User-friendly interfaces, utility apps, and software were all created with one common aspiration: to make life easier, i.e. to increase the comfort of the user. For example, a Wii remote suffices its purpose for a game of Mario Kart, but a remote holder in the shape of a steering wheel is, metaphorically, what technology tries to achieve. Having established that technology is here to try and do "good" what we need to understand is that the detrimental effects only occur with prolonged use. No one can sustain themselves with an unlimited supply of a single food product, right? Similarly, when technology is used for productivity it is beneficial but when you spend 16 hours on Netflix finishing an entire season of Suits in one day, you need help. My point being, limits aren't only effective in maths. Certain limitations, be it self imposed or forced, can prove to be beneficial to both productivity and health. Maybe someone can write a program to limit the use of technology? Another factor that influences the inclusion of technology is the demand for alternatives. Living in Kolkata, one faces refusal from cab drivers quite often. Enter Uber and Ola, literally apps that book cabs. The unsettled debate whether this inclusion of technology is advantageous or not is for online forums and interschool competitions to decide. I'm off to set Youtube to remind me after I've watched 45 minutes of Unbox Therapy or random scenes from The Big Bang Theory.
item.excerpt:encoded: As much as my nerdy, math-loving self wants, I can't make this blog about calculus. This is supposed to be about the integration of technology, focus Ansh. Focus.

item.title: Apple's Garden of Eden
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded: Ever since the advent of the Macintosh there exists a trend of "end-to-end" connectivity for most of Apple's devices. The fact that Apple's devices don't bond well with other platforms and devices is one of the things that makes Apple so unique. However, in recent news from the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) 2019; Apple is, reportedly, going to collaborate. LG's new TVs will support Apple's Airplay 2 and HomeKit and Samsung TVs will support iTunes as well. So, the content which is endemic to the Apple experience, be it TV shows, movies, podcasts, will now be availible on other platforms. And to think one of Apple's biggest competitors in the smartphone market, Samsung. This change may appear trivial at first glance but it's crucial to note that such a 'behaviour' is very uncommon for Apple. Apple as a tech giant has so far set itself aside from the competition by isolating itself within a metaphorical walled garden of Eden. Apple users may take whatever lay in the garden (for 7 easy installments of $12) but must never scale the high walls. In a recent video by Unbox Therapy on YouTube, Lewis stated his own analysis of this change and stated that Apple may probably just be doing this in response to the decreasing iPhone sales in the south east Asian market. What is crucial to note at this juncture is that most successful companies or products within the tech market of the current decade work across platforms, like Amazon or Google. This could be taken as a prompt towards Apple to rethink how it brands itself entirely. The primary concern of Apple to play this move would probably be to increase its viewership. The idea is to get more people into Apple's content and services so eventually they might move into the Apple ecosystem in its entirety. Based on posts on The Verge and on Investors Apple is investing about $1 Billion solely on content and a streaming video service to supposedly compete with Netflix and Amazon Prime Video. Although this is quite uncoventional for Apple, it seems like a step in the right direction. With an increase in use of smart televisions no one wants to buy a separate Apple TV when you already have various streaming services that work across various television brands. Until now the only way to interact with Apple's services was to purchase its hardware. Until now.
item.excerpt:encoded: Until now the only way to interact with Apple's services was to purchase its hardware. Until now.

item.title: The Tech Shift
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded: A lot of change has recently spiked up in the technology industry. Perhaps the most inticing of them all is the initiative taken by large tech giants like Apple and Samsung to target the South East Asian market. For a relatively long period of time Apple dominated the technology market on the momentum that the iPhone granted the company. Ever since the advent of the first iPhone, Apple seems to have a 10 step lead on the industry. However, that quorum is changing. A lot of recent statistics from various sources including Wall Street depict a drastic fall in Apple's sales specifically in India and China. Having spent about 7 years in India myself, one of the things that came into my observation is the fact that Apple neither has a manufacturing line in India nor an official Apple Store, therefore consumers have to pay significant amounts as customs and tariffs. Added to this is the fact that most people who purchase smartphones in south east Asia are extremely well reasearched. The iPhone 6S and SE have been made in India since May 2017, however, it becomes crucial to note that in most cases iPhone users did not upgrade after their purchase of iPhone 6 or SE. To supposedly combat this stagnancy Apple has announced recently that it will begin manufacturing its luxury line of smartphones, like the iPhone X, XS, and XR in India. With the ongoing trade war between the United States of America and China this move seems only logical to keep Apple afloat in the fastest growing tech market. By making products more affordable by localising the manufacturing process Apple should be able to regain a stand in this region. On the other front, Samsung has also announced a new line of smartphones: the Galaxy M series (Where M is dubbed for millenials) targeted at around $150 or Rs. 10,000. Samsung seems to be targeting the average consumer for an increased reach. Based on Samsungs official site phones in the M series are to have an infinity-V display (like on the OnePlus 6T) , 3GB of RAM, will run Android 8.1 Oreo, and have a 5000mAh battery. Obataining decent specs like these within this price range is something relatively new and pretty unconventional for a luxury brand like Samsung. But considering that Samsung does build phones from scratch without purchasing hardware may give it the edge into achieving such a price point without losses. Xiaomi isn't far behind, being the leader in the south east asian market they have recently annunced the Redmi Note 7 for around $150 (~Rs.10,000) with a 48 Megapixel camera, 4000 mAh battery and a 6.3 inch screen. Understand at this point that the focus for most companies now has become the mid to low range price devices that appeal to a wider audience. We see the biggest batteries in the mid and low range of phones, not in the luxury brands. There seems to exist an apparent shift of priority of tech companies to target a wider range of audience, first by targetting the moderately average consumer. By shifting the manufacturing to India, companies can take advantage of readily availible labor and a rapidly aware and growing market.
item.excerpt:encoded: There seems to exist an apparent shift of priority of tech companies to target a wider range of audience, first by targetting the moderately average consumer.

item.title: Data
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded: Shoutout to Ayush Tanna for the topic Throughout the concluding months of 2018, we witnessed a series of testifications on the part of large tech companies like Google, Apple, and Facebook in presence of United State senators. The primary concern, it seems, is privacy, security, and management of user data. In April 2018, a bill was passed in the US senate pertaining to Social Media Privacy Protection and Consumer Rights. In lieu of this change and a similar change in the EU's policy regarding privacy a lot of companies updated their privacy policy (most of us got the notifications) to accomodate the new provisions. In particular, there were 4 hearings with tech giants to discuss, and to a great extent accuse them, of content sharing and using personal information for advertisements and marketing. With the increased popularity of Big Data implementations to facilitate advertisements there seems to be a growing concern about the way we interact on the internet. Perhaps everyone just saw Fast & Furious 7 and got intimidated by the God's Eye. But jokes apart, it becomes crucial to note, that if companies centered around mass consumerism cannot gain the trust of their users, it leads to a complex bit of a situation. Most companies use user data in the form of cookies to better accustom ad content endemic to a particular computer or user, most people don't know how cookies work. The efforts of the US senate are definately commendable but they lack in the implementation of these protocols. I mean no offense to anybody, but understand that members of the senate who conducted the hearing are all past their middle ages. There were questions about whether Google can track location and why President Trump's picture comes up every time you Google 'idiot.' The 21st Century is a digital book, where content is based on tags and hashtags, where popular feed comes under the trending tab based on the number of views per unit time. The notion that tech companies like Google or Apple execute personal bias and agenda is simply unrealistic. Tech giants are respectfully shutting down the allegations made by speculatists and continuing on their projected path of innovation and progress. Apple, Google, Amazon, and Facebook haven't shyed away from questions. They've stepped up, taken responsibility and have responded to questions and allegations with diplomacy. To ensure the complete security and transparency in instances like these it becomes imperative to involve a younger group of people who are well acquainted with the know-how of technology and the internet.
item.excerpt:encoded: In April 2018, a bill was passed in the US senate pertaining to Social Media Privacy Protection and Consumer Rights.

item.title: Dependancy
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
Most of human history has guided itself to not only creating but sustaining the most comfortable environment possible. We've spent millenia trying to make our surroundings adjust to our needs. Part of our pitch to acomplish this goal is the advent of computing devices.
Both Steve Jobs and Bill Gates had a vision to increase the accessibility of computing devices to the common public. Our access to this form of technology brought out one of the greatest revolutions in common lifestyles. As devices became 'smarter' and more mobile we increased the amount of services they could perform for us. Computer Programming boomed and possibilities revealed themselves. What we do with this technology is completely seamless. We have cars that can drive themselves, robots who can assemble machines better than us, and oh the coffee machines are brilliant.
Just like every coin has two sides a massive growth in technology and change in our lifestyle can surely cause some side effects right? Nothing can be too easy right? The same technology that produces energy via nuclear reactions can cause catastrophic damage to cities. The same technology that allows us to read articles can affect our health due to increased exposure.
What I try to do with the help of this blog is simply bring things into perspective. It has often been an observation that we become so narrow sighted with the potential of technology that we often forget not only its side effects but also other worldly things that prove to be equally as engaging. People my age were born in a time where mobile phones were developing at a rapid rate, Windows 95 was awesome, and we had those toy phones where we'd try to get all the rings on the vertical stick. Most of us have seen technology grow from its roots. But this nostalgia won't get us anywhere.
Comfort comes at a cost. It is quite interesting to note that even though our accessibility to technology and knowledge has increased, we're more stressed out in our lives that ever before. The modern revolution has brought about a new sense of complexity. We still stress but just not about survival. In my personal opinion, most of these problems are 'man-made.' We boast of our technological advancements and exclaim how technology has made our lives easier, but is that statement really true?
Technology to a large extent has overpowered us. We're stressed out about the latest updates, Inbox being replaced by Gmail, skepticism with autonomus vehicles, etc. The point I try to make here is simply the necessity to take a step back and regroup. It becomes essential to understand and control the way we use technology.
We need to come to terms with the reality that we live in an extremely fast paced life, but at the same time we cannot let our actions be governed involuntarily.
item.excerpt:encoded: Most of human history has guided itself to not only creating but sustaining the most comfortable environment possible. Is it worth it?

item.title: More Inclusion, Less Liberalism
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded: Too much of anything is dangerous. Be it that extra double chocolate cookie or those seven more Brussel sprouts that your mom forces you to eat. Checkmate huh? Keeping aside those nuances of your dinner, let's talk about the Great Liberalism Paradox. Conventional education has led us to strong beliefs of tolerance towards all of humanity and even animals. This ideology seems morally correct at first glance, but we have just begun to understand its extended repercussions. Hear me out here, as tolerance towards various social groups increases there is a strictly decreasing trend in restrictions per se. The more tolerant society becomes, the more freely people can express all kinds of thoughts and ideas. Sure this sounds great, but it means that the negative or hurtful ideas will spread as easily as the positive ones. But wait, that's illegal? We want people to equivocate their opinions, we want to hear thoughts and create a more inclusive society. But simply having more tolerance isn't the way. A filter needs to exist which filters morally unacceptable propaganda. Then again, what may be morally correct to one could be morally flawed to another. What motivated me to write this post today is a simple headline that reads, "Google has removed an app that advised people on “recovery from same-sex attraction” from its download store after one of the United States’ top LGBT+ charities suspended the tech company from a gay and transgender rights ranking." An issue or movement like LGBTQ+ is certainly not globally accepted, which stance is morally correct, therefore, needs to be decided by either authorities or the global community. Neither of which come at a conclusion. I do seem to be raising more questions than I can answer. Here's the deal. Believe it or not, the world has become increasingly sensitive to words, propaganda, and opinions. It isn't possible to act freely without having to concern yourself with being politically correct. Our current predicament necessitates that we take a step back. An optimum level of tolerance would be one where we are concerned about society but do not tolerate extremist ideologies.
item.excerpt:encoded: Could increasing tolerance lead to division of society? Could inclusion conpromise liberalism?

item.title: Surveillance Capitalism
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
Shoutout to Malay Vasa for the topic

Human civilization has seen multiple transitions pertaining to a long standing business model. From Coal & Fuel, to Spices, even weird leaves that taste good in hot water: Tea. The common attribute between business models till today has been the tangibility of their products. 

However, we enter a world where 'tangibility' of products is no longer a limitation. Economies all over the world move towards a more service centric model. The age of Information. These progressive yet quick changes trigger a new business model entirely, one that's built on services and data. Welcome to the age of Surveillance Capitalism.

If you still think that looking up something on a search engine or creating an account on social media is free, think again. Websites and web services put forth a privacy policy that governs their right on our data and activities since we blatantly skip reading and click on 'Accept Privacy Policy.' What matters most to most tech companies is our Data. It allows them to customize and fine tune their services to our needs and desires, pretty neat huh? Wait for it, though.

Background

Although this form of capitalism exists since the boom of the internet, say roughly 2008-2010, there has been much ado about the same in the media recently. The rising concerns regarding privacy and data security are quite closely related to this trend. Recent hearing between the US Senate and four very specific tech giants have presented the common public with a notion of ambiguity when it comes to Big Data, Artificial Intelligence, and Cookies. While officials in the US Senate somewhat failed to jostle tech giants, a more aware class of individuals, computer enthusiasts, and learners stepped forward and started questioning the motives and methods of such tech giants. It becomes extremely pertinent, therefore, to increase transparency and awareness about the current long standing business model.

The Necessity of Surveillance Capitalism

  1. Reduction of sales in the 'tangible' market: According to recent trends, consumers are less likely to change their smartphones with every new release. Hence, explaining why tech companies are now targeting the mid-tier markets.
  2. The demand for more personalized services: Facilities like cookies in web browsers allow for a more user centric display of content. This has slowly become not only a norm, but rather a common expectation for users.
  3. Shift to a service centered market: Following reduction in sales of tangible products, companies have moved on to various services like streaming, music, and even mainstream Television.

The above observations make it quite clear that Surveillance Capitalism has well established itself as the business model of the internet. It has become the common methodology for companies to earn revenue and most likely, cannot be changed. Regardless it is essential to discuss it for understanding the nature of our economy and how technology is changing it.

How does Surveillance Capitalism Work?

To answer this question in the simplest way possible: think of your parents. They know what you like and dislike. They know how to adapt to your varying moods. All this because, your parents have nurtured you, watched you grow, and observed your behaviour. Now imagine that instead of your parents, it was simply a machine. A significant bit of code that could suggest new products based not only on your previous orders but also on your search history. Expand the horizon to not only the search history of a particular website, but all of your searches on all of the websites you visit, at any given day and time.

This may seem alarming but these practices have been taking place for longer than one might expect. Even in private browsing, like incognito mode, your cookies and preferences are saved. A website will then adjust accordingly to suggest items and services more personalized. This model of changing web content based on individual users really appeals to your target audience rather than having one generalized content view for every single person. If you think about it, it's actually pretty smart.

A couple of questions arise here, nonetheless. What are the data collection methods? Did users agree to it? Do these practices violate our fundamental rights? And most importantly, what does it cost us?

Ethics

At our current standpoint, the applied methodology of Surveillance Capitalism as seen in case studies of major tech companies, this entire business model falls in the grey area when it comes to ethics. It seems as though recent hearings of large tech companies has sparked a sense of awareness among the common masses, especially in first world countries. And it seems completely justified. Users do have the right to know how their information is being used and for what purpose.

The Dilemma

Pertaining steadfast to the current dynamic, a few issues come to mind.

Firstly, it becomes the right of consumers to choose whether they wish to opt into or out of said dynamic. No consumer should be coerced into obeying this particular business model. However, giving this choice to individuals poses a great problem for companies with capitalist ventures. Companies would most likely argue for the use of data collection methods in order to appeal to a more concise target audience. In many ways Surveillance Capitalism has become one of the if not the major source of revenue for service providers.

Secondly, the recent trend regarding people's notions about data collection methods hasn't been all that positive towards industries. Most people seem to be unaware about the existence of this business model, let alone how it functions. This is particularly in the case of developing countries.

Furthermore, if data collection and usage by said companies is unethical or maybe even illegal, who is there to check them? Currently, there seems to be no "line" drawn to the extent and application of Surveillance Capitalism

Resolutions

Solving this so called issue requires much more than just consumer and company cooperation. If deemed unfit or unethical, we would probably have to do away with this particular business model and find a substitute. Which won't be easy considering the current trends of market outlined in previous sections. Therefore, it seems fit at this stage, that consumers be rigorously made aware of the entire modus operandi of Surveillance Capitalism by the companies who use it.
item.excerpt:encoded: If you still think that looking up something on a search engine or creating an account on social media is free, think again. What matters most to companies is our Data. It allows them to customize and fine tune their services to our needs and desires, pretty neat huh? Wait for it, though.

A fascinating look at modern shifts in online commerce! There's lot of fodder for thoughtful discussion here.

item.title: Cold War II
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
In a previous blog post exploring the concept of Egoistic Altruism, it was outlined that humans are more valuable to us alive than dead due to the dynamic of a positive sum game the global economy is presently in. This is probably an extremely valid reason why tensions between the United States and China have escalated beyond fathomable control, yet both nations are, militarily speaking, quiet.

Ever since the dawn of the Trump administration in the United States there seems to be a long standing fascination with China in its entirety. Instead of providing a source for that statement, I'll let the number of Trump+China memes speak for themselves. And this "fascination" is pretty much justified (economically, that is). China persists as the fastest growing economy, the technology sector is booming, and the young workforce is quite intellectual.

It is seemingly due to these reasons that there seems to exist a Trade War between the two prominent nations, which is taking place on a largely separate diplomatic track. Notably since early 2018, Trump has been placing an escalating series of tariffs on Chinese imports in order to force leaders to the bargaining table, with China retaliating with its own tariffs, and increased tension as various summits have fallen through. This is proving to be quite an issue for tech companies who have globalized their operations and are now looking for alternatives.

Just like a child between two bickering parents, the most recent victim of this cold war is the company Huawei Technologies. In many ways Huawei products prove to be the best of both worlds, Chinese hardware with US branded software like Android. Recently, the US government blacklisted the company citing unsaid security concerns.

Source: https://www.theverge.com/2019/5/23/18637836/trump-huawei-ban-explanation-trade-deal-national-security-risk

Furthermore, companies like Google and Panasonic have responded to the same. Google has officially revoked Huawei's licence to use their mobile operating system Android. It may seem now that Huawei has been led to the grave considering it no longer has an operating system. However, Huawei, and even Samsung for that matter, has been planning for such a contingency.

In an industry its never smart to start depending on one particular product, service or licence that may affect your entire product lineup. Which is why Samsung is trying to create its own services like Bixby in the intention of moving further from the android ecosystem. Huawei too, has been quietly working on its own backup operating system for its mobile devices. This OS is speculated to come to Huawei mobile devices late this year.

Regardless, this poses quite an issue for Huawei. What if soon Microsoft revokes its Windows licence for Huawei's PC lineup. Huawei may not even be capable of creating separate operating systems for its varying product lineups.

This even raises certain concerns on how far these two nations are willing to go in order to "win."

But Huawei Technologies, is like the second largest tech company in the world for consumer devices. They may have a few tricks or lines of code up their sleeves. Let's see how the cards play out.
item.excerpt:encoded: Ever since the dawn of the Trump administration in the United States there seems to be a long standing fascination with China in its entirety. Instead of providing a source for that statement, I'll let the number of Trump+China memes speak for themselves.

item.title: Tech Ethics
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
Shoutout to Carissa Lintao for the topic.

Debates around morality and ethics have prevailed since the dawn of civilization. In fact, it is ethics and morals that classify us as civilized individuals. However, there never was and probably never will be a unified code that we consider as ethics. Cultural diversity prompts the subjective nature of ethics. What may be ethical for one set of people, may be taboo for another set.

The 21st century provides us, further, with a new paradigm to be considered. The ethics that revolve around technology and cyberspace. Morals governing cyberspace can be highly intricate and controversial, which paves the way for a "grey area" of principles.

On the very onset it is crucial to note that unlike the physical world; cyberspace lacks 'law enforcement'. Sure, your Internet Service Provider (ISP) can track if you visit malicious websites, or the government can forbid people from accessing certain networks. But, none of those methods really stop cybercrime and cyber-threats.

The Necessity

In an earlier blog on Surveillance Capitalism I outlined measures taken by various companies to appeal to their target audience and categorised them as 'questionable'. However, today we rise above the standpoint of consumerism and profit. Ethical use of cyberspace becomes a matter of national and international security.

Maintaining surveillance on users primarily to deter a cyber attack or crime would be one way to ensure decent use of cyberspace. Surveillance grants the power of reconnaissance and awareness. The current state of cyber wars across the globe require a seemingly illegal approach to data collection and deterrence. If an entity were to stick to hard rules they'd be walking towards a battlefield, blindfolded.

The Paradox

We've discussed the significance of regulating and managing cyberspace, yet we are faced with a paradox affecting two very different instances:

  1. National Interest: Often times, it would be in the national interest of certain governments to monitor activity in cyberspace. Although effective, this violates fundamental rights of people, since they may not have provided explicit consent for the same.
  2. Capitalist Motive: Pertaining to the current business model of Surveillance Capitalism, most companies gather data for their profit. However, without consumers having a general understanding of these data collection methods it becomes seemingly 'unethical'.

A common question at this juncture would be, how do important tech entities operate now?
Ans: Most tech entities take adavntages of loopholes in laws and operate in "grey areas". For example, when issues of national security arises, organizations may even choose to violate certain rights of individuals for "the greater good".

Resolutions

Defining ethics in tech seems to be a herculean task. So let's start smaller. Characteristics of information flow in the 21st Century prompt the urgent need for a comprehensive data security model. One that is governed by young minds.

  • Certain sites with malicious content can be blocked locally but there will always be way to access them, unless these sites are banned from all locations.
  • Creation of consumer applications and interfaces should hopefully go through a screening process of usability and potential to assess certain 'ethics'.
  • Consumers and the general public should be made aware of data collection methods and reasons. Authorities ought to govern by understanding, not by force.
  • Stricter penalties for ethics and privacy violations could also help.

All in all, the dicey situation of surveillance and ethics in cyberspace demands a comprehensive yet quick solution.
item.excerpt:encoded: What may be ethical for one set of people, may be taboo for another set. The 21st century provides us, further, with a new paradigm to be considered. The ethics that revolve around technology and cyberspace.

item.title: One Device
item.dc:creator: ansh1901
item.content:encoded:
On the very onset, I would like to apologize to the physics enthusiasts out there who still dream of unifying Quantum Mechanics with Gravitational phenomenon.

When you think about underlying motives and goals of varying products and developments in the Tech Industry, there appears a simple, sofisticated pattern. Over the last few decades, appliances (not merely restricted to smart devices) have a tendency of becoming smaller, more power efficient, and offering a wider range of services. But what exactly is the end goal? What does modern day technology hope to achieve (apart from the very lucrative profits) ?

Technology in and of itself is simply appliances and devices that tend to make our lives easier, more convenient. Having established the general objective of technology in its entirety, it is crucial to note the path manufacturers and developers take to achieve said goal.

In an interview with Apple's marketing director, a Grand Theory of Apple was stated. The basic idea was to gradually reduce and eliminate the need for bigger devices and make say, the Apple Watch capable of a Mac. This movement towards smaller, more compact devices has another very crucial characteristic to it. The wearable nature of small devices like the Apple Watch itself.

Another trend to note would be the reduction in sales of smartphones. Due to the increase in efficiency of devices and their hardware, coupled with the rising prices of a new smart phone most people would rather spend a significant amount on a flagship level phone and then hold on to it for at least 3 years. Now this doesn't mean an eventual halt in the smart phone market, but rather a metamorphosis of the same. While smartphone sales may have taken a hit in 2018 - 19, Samsung reportedly saw a tremendous increase in its Watch sales last year.

All this is a clear indication of the direction the current Tech Market is headed towards. Wearable devices would probably be the future of modern day computing. And, maybe someday you could hook up your smart watch with that bezel-less curved display to an external GPU, daisy-chain it to a monitor and some peripherals and edit on Final Cut Pro or code another Artificial Intelligence to do your tasks.

Photo by rawpixel.com from Pexels
